00035 // Used to mark special files. The original ESM files are given
00036 // special treatment in a few places, most noticably in loading and
00037 // filtering out "dirtly" GMST entries correctly.
00038 enum SpecialFile
00039   {
00040     SF_Other,
00041     SF_Morrowind,
00042     SF_Tribunal,
00043     SF_Bloodmoon
00044   };
00045 
00046 /* A structure used for holding fixed-length strings. In the case of
00047    LEN=4, it can be more efficient to match the string as a 32 bit
00048    number, therefore the struct is implemented as a union with an int.
00049  */
00050 template <int LEN>
00051 union NAME_T
00052 {
00053   char name[LEN];
00054   int32_t val;
00055 
00056   bool operator==(const char *str)
00057   {
00058     for(int i=0; i<LEN; i++)
00059       if(name[i] != str[i]) return false;
00060       else if(name[i] == 0) return true;
00061     return str[LEN] == 0;
00062   }
00063   bool operator!=(const char *str) { return !((*this)==str); }
00064 
00065   bool operator==(const std::string &str)
00066   {
00067     return (*this) == str.c_str();
00068   }
00069   bool operator!=(const std::string &str) { return !((*this)==str); }
00070 
00071   bool operator==(int v) { return v == val; }
00072   bool operator!=(int v) { return v != val; }
00073 
00074   std::string toString() const { return std::string(name, strnlen(name, LEN)); }
00075 };
00076 
00077 typedef NAME_T<4> NAME;
00078 typedef NAME_T<32> NAME32;
00079 typedef NAME_T<64> NAME64;
00080 typedef NAME_T<256> NAME256;
00081 
00082 #pragma pack(push)
00083 #pragma pack(1)
00084 
00085 struct HEDRstruct
00086 {
00087   /* File format version. This is actually a float, the supported
00088      versions are 1.2 and 1.3. These correspond to:
00089      1.2 = 0x3f99999a and 1.3 = 0x3fa66666
00090   */
00091   int version;
00092   int type;           // 0=esp, 1=esm, 32=ess
00093   NAME32 author;      // Author's name
00094   NAME256 desc;       // File description
00095   int records;        // Number of records? Not used.
00096 };
00097 
00098 // Defines another files (esm or esp) that this file depends upon.
00099 struct MasterData
00100 {
00101   std::string name;
00102   uint64_t size;
00103 };
00104 
00105 // Data that is only present in save game files
00106 struct SaveData
00107 {
00108   float pos[6];     // Player position and rotation
00109   NAME64 cell;      // Cell name
00110   float unk2;       // Unknown value - possibly game time?
00111   NAME32 player;    // Player name
00112 };
00113 #pragma pack(pop)
00114 
00115 
00116 /* This struct defines a file 'context' which can be saved and later
00117    restored by an ESMReader instance. It will save the position within
00118    a file, and when restored will let you read from that position as
00119    if you never left it.
00120  */
00121 struct ESM_Context
00122 {
00123   std::string filename;
00124   uint32_t leftRec, leftSub;
00125   size_t leftFile;
00126   NAME recName, subName;
00127   HEDRstruct header;
00128 
00129   // True if subName has been read but not used.
00130   bool subCached;
00131 
00132   // File position. Only used for stored contexts, not regularly
00133   // updated within the reader itself.
00134   size_t filePos;
00135 };

00196   /*************************************************************************
00197    *
00198    *  Medium-level reading shortcuts

00201 
00202   // Read data of a given type, stored in a subrecord of a given name
00203   template <typename X>
00204   void getHNT(X &x, const char* name)
00205   {
00206     getSubNameIs(name);
00207     getHT(x);
00208   }
00209 
00210   // Optional version of getHNT
00211   template <typename X>
00212   void getHNOT(X &x, const char* name)
00213   {
00214       if(isNextSub(name))
00215           getHT(x);
00216   }
00217 
00218   // Version with extra size checking, to make sure the compiler
00219   // doesn't mess up our struct padding.
00220   template <typename X>
00221   void getHNT(X &x, const char* name, int size)
00222   {
00223       assert(sizeof(X) == size);
00224       getSubNameIs(name);
00225       getHT(x);
00226   }
00227 
00228   int64_t getHNLong(const char *name);
00229 
00230   // Get data of a given type/size, including subrecord header
00231   template <typename X>
00232   void getHT(X &x)
00233   {
00234       getSubHeader();
00235       if (mCtx.leftSub != sizeof(X))
00236           fail("getHT(): subrecord size mismatch");
00237       getT(x);
00238   }
00239 
00240   // Version with extra size checking, to make sure the compiler
00241   // doesn't mess up our struct padding.
00242   template <typename X>
00243   void getHT(X &x, int size)
00244   {
00245       assert(sizeof(X) == size);
00246       getHT(x);
00247   }
00248 
00249   // Read a string by the given name if it is the next record.
00250   std::string getHNOString(const char* name);
00251 
00252   // Read a string with the given sub-record name
00253   std::string getHNString(const char* name);
00254 
00255   // Read a string, including the sub-record header (but not the name)
00256   std::string getHString();

00295      sub-record as well. leftSub contains size of current sub-record.
00296   */

00319   /* Read record header. This updatesleftFile BEYOND the data that
00320      follows the header, ie beyond the entire record. You should use
00321      leftRec to orient yourself inside the record itself.
00322   */
00323   void getRecHeader() { uint32_t u; getRecHeader(u); }
00324   void getRecHeader(uint32_t &flags);
00325 
00326   bool hasMoreRecs() { return mCtx.leftFile > 0; }
00327   bool hasMoreSubs() { return mCtx.leftRec > 0; }

00337   void getT(X &x) { getExact(&x, sizeof(X)); }
00338 
00339   void getExact(void*x, int size);
00340   void getName(NAME &name) { getT(name); }
00341   void getUint(uint32_t &u) { getT(u); }
00342 
00343   // Read the next 'size' bytes and return them as a string. Converts
00344   // them from native encoding to UTF8 in the process.
00345   std::string getString(int size);
00346
